Schedule:
Autumn E4 (Tues 13-17, Fri 8-12) and Spring F4 (Tues 13-17, Fri 8-12)
A detailed schedule will be announced on DTU Learn at the begining of the course.
Location:
Campus Lyngby
The room for the individual teaching sessions will be announced on DTU Learn.
Scope and form:
Course 38109 is the advanced course following course 38103.

In 38103 the student group have taken the first steps on learning and executing entrepreneurship (incubation). X-Tech+ will take the form of an accelerator and focuses on maturing the technology, the business and acceleration through strategic work with a 'avisory baord' from DTU's Board Education.

The course will also be using peer-to-peer learning, in class teaching and group supervision.
Date of examination: Decide with teacher, The date of examination will be published at the course kick off.
Type of assessment:
Oral examination and reports
The assessment takes place as an Advisory Board meeting, where the group of students conducts an Advisory Board Meeting with their Advisory Board from DTU's Board Education. Prior to the meeting the student group have handed in a Development Plan, which is the foundations for the themes in the oral exam. The assessment is based on the written report (Development Plan) and the oral examination. The elements are given equal weight. The work is conducted in groups, but evaluated individually. The course is not suited for re-exam, and students who have not passed the course must attend the course again.
Aid:
:
A monitor will be avaliable.

Mandatory Prerequisites: 38103 or 38203 , X-Tech+ is the advanced course building on course 38103. To participate you must be part of a startup-project from course 38103, i.e. participation is based on a startup-project from course 38103, but the team might not be the same. One student, from course 38103, continues the startup-project with a new team of minimum 3 persons total.

General course objectives:
General course objectives
The course is set in an accelerator format and emphasises a learning by doing philosophy.
To speed up the learning process, we bring together the students from X-Tech+ with experienced professionals taking part in DTU's Board Education. The collaboration will help emphasise the importance of the methods and theory being taught in the course.

The overall course objective is to acceleratre the development and professionalise the teams from X-Tech (38103), to be able to raise investment and spinout new impactfull tech-startups.
Learning objectives:
A student who has met the objectives of the course will be able to:
Explain which laws and regulations particularly affect startups, as well as this specific startup, and explain what precautions it requires of the startup.
Draw up a budget that can be used in dialogue with potential investors.
Demonstrate a 'product/market fit'.
Analyse the recruitment needs in the startup, at the operational and strategic level.
Analyse the market and the competitive situation and identify which position the startup must take in order to achieve a competitive position in the market.
Analyse the startup's Innovation Readiness Level and identify the most important development points and strategies for achieving these that contribute to making the startup investment-ready.
Argue for the societal 'impact' the startup has (social, environmental and financial).
Assess the current composition of the 'advisory board' as well as reflect on how a future 'advisory board' should be composed in order to increase the value of this and of the startup.
Formulate a strategy for 'IPR' (Intellectual property rights) that strengthens the startup's investment potential (if relevant).
Formulate a funding strategy, based on concrete development goals and an analysis of the need for funding, soft as well as hard.
Formulate a communication strategy and activity plan, as well as design a core narrative and communication products (article) that communicate the startup externally.
Formulate a development plan, execute on it and reflect on changes and their strategic significance.
Content:
The course covers startup law, finance, market and competition analysis, recruitment, 'IRL', 'impact', 'IPR', funding and communication. the course is the advanced course building on course 38103.

The individual startups are based on different technologies, and therefore the course is suitable for all study lines across DTU.
As the technical development is a prerequisite for the development of the startup, this is a main point of focus in the course, but due to the diversity of technologies this is not covered in teaching, but time is set aside for the work.

The final deliverable of the course is a development plan. The course is examined as an advisory board meeting, based on the development plan handed in.
Course literature:
Mandatory reading:

- Nielsen, Nicolaj Højer, 2017, Startup Funding.

- Fisher III, William W. and Oberholzer-Gee, Felix, 2013, Strategic Management of Intellectual Property, California Management Review, Vol. 55, No. 4, pp. 157–183.

- Andhov, Alexandra, 2020, Start-Up Law, Edward Elgar Publishing Ltd.

- Gruber, Marc and Tal, Sharon, 2017, Where to play, Pearson Education Limited.

- Gassmann, Oliver; Frankenberger, Karolin and Choudury, Michaela, 2020, The Business Model Navigator, 55 business models, Pearson Education Limited.

- Kounalakis, Markos; Banks, Drew and Daus, Kim, 1999, Beyond Spin, John Wiley & Sons.


Recommended reading:

- Kumar, Vijay, 2013, 101 Design Methods, John Wiley & Sons.

- Swindling, Linda, 2013, Stop Complainers and Energy Drainers, John Wiley & Sons.

- Ries, Eric, 2011, The Lean Startup, Penguin Random House.
Remarks:
An agreement on further collaboration or transfer of rights to the 'Startup' between the 'Project Proposer' from course 38103 and the students must be in place upon registration.

Denmark has a strong Startup Ecosytem, with strong programmes offering support for Startups. The course expects all student groups to be active in and work strategically with how they can contribute to and make use of these offerings.

Each participating team receives 20.000 DKK for maturing the Startup (technology). The funds are to be used during the duration of the course or the funds will lapse.
All participating teams are competing for 100.000 DKK, which is the main prize for the X-Tech Programme.
